Initial dose, known amount of ingestion: Administer a total dose equal to amount of isoniazid ingested, up to a maximum of 5 grams or 70 mg/kg. Administer at a rate of 0.5 to 1 g/minute.
Administer at 0.5 to 1 g/minute. May repeat dose every 5 to 10 minutes to control seizures or CNS toxicity.

Initial dose, known amount of ingestion: Administer a total dose equal to amount of isoniazid ingested. Initially administer 5 g over 30 minutes. If required, the remainder may be administered by IV infusion over the next 1 to 2 hours.

AdditionalNotes.value: INFANTS: pyridoxine-dependent seizures. Oral route preferred.
CHILDREN: Dietary deficiency. Reduce dose after 3 weeks to 1.5 to 2.5 mg daily in an oral multivitamin
ADULT: Dietary deficiency. After 3 weeks, switch to 2 to 5 mg/day orally.
ADULT: Pyridoxine-dependency syndrome. Switch to oral pryidoxine 30mg/day once patient responds.
ADULT: Pyridoxine deficiency due to Isoniazid treatment. Follow with oral pyridoxine 30 mg/day.
ADULT: Cycloserine poisoning. Higher doses may be required (300 mg is usual dose).
ADULT: Acute Isoniazid poisoning. Known amount of Isoniazid ingested greater than 10 grams.

Administer until seizures stop of the Maximum initial dose is administered. May repeat every 5 to 10 minutes to control seizures or CNS toxicity. If seizures stop before the initial pyridoxine dose, administer the initial dose over 4 to 6 hours.
ADULT: Gyromitra mushroom poisoning. Maximum dose: 10 grams.
ADULT: Ethylene Glycol poisoning. Continue treatment until ethylene glycol concentration is less than 3 mmol/L and there is no evidence of acidosis or end-organ dmamage (renal failure).
ADULT: Acute Isoniazid poisoning. Amount of Isoniazid ingested is NOT known.
